labels.name: wontfix

issues.title: det: more use cases
issues.author: cabo
issues.body:
Use Wolf's list of use cases <https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cbor/RaZfA5XLMRQ65kKu_XstEPwMK2k>
to generate a more complete list in det.

issues.title: det: Add pseudocode for preferred encoding and numeric reduction
issues.author: cabo

comments.author: hildjj
comments.body: Is this issue overcome by events?

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
I do think that we want to have some such pseudocode.
The question is whether it belongs into the normative document for CDE or in the determinism explainer ("det").
We also haven't decided on any role that the explainer could play in the WG.

issues.title: terminology: f16, float16, binary16
issues.author: cabo
issues.body:
Do not mix up these terms:

* f16 (Rust name for a platform level storage type),
* float16 (CDDL name for a floating point precision and range), and 
* binary16 (IEEE 754 name for a binary representation of floating point values).

(and 32, 64).

comments.author: hildjj
comments.body: Is this issue overcome by events?

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
CDE currently doesn't mention these different concepts.
The explainer does, but I don't find any place that needs immediate attention.
(Obviously, we want to keep the principle in mind.)

issues.title: additional information in integers vs doubles
issues.author: dwaite
issues.body:
In the section on reducing floating point numbers to integers, I believe it would be appropriate to clearly specify behavior of other floating point reductions, e.g. reducing 0.5 from double to a half-width float.

In addition, I believe the behavior needs to be defined as to what an application should do when conversion of an integer to a floating point number is in itself lossy, e.g. what to do if an application expects a double but the CBOR value received is the decimal 9007199254740993. Silent truncation would make the round-trip non-deterministic.

comments.author: hildjj
comments.body: See the section on [preferred serialization](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8949.html#name-preferred-serialization) in RFC8949, and read the dCBOR [draft](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-mcnally-deterministic-cbor-07.html), then see what else this spec needs?

issues.title: CDE: More explicitly disallow equivalent map keys
issues.author: cabo
issues.body:
Make the requirement that a CDE-encoded data item does not contain duplicate (or equivalent) keys in its maps more explicit.

Archived-At: <https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cbor/bRgglMTgXsdpkKvxToNSjLt4-Qo>

issues.title: Terminology: preferred serialization or preferred encoding
issues.author: laurencelundblade
issues.body:
"preferred serialization" (lower case) is used 23 times in RFC 8949.

"preferred encoding" (lower case) is used once parenthetically in RFC 8949.

This draft uses "preferred encoding" (upper and lower case) 6 times.

This draft uses "preferred serialization" once, plus some use in PRs.

Probably this draft should exclusively use "preferred serialization" in lower case. We did a go around in RATS/EAT about upper/lower case and even though RATS architecture uses upper case, EAT switched to lower case as much more readable.

issues.title: Remove Application Profiles
issues.author: laurencelundblade
issues.body:
Application Profiles seem like an unnecessary complexity to me in an area that (I think) we're trying to make simpler.

I look at this draft as a really useful rewording of some important stuff in section 4 and 5 of RFC 8949. Those sections of 8949 are a bit complicated for readers, so this draft should be simple.

So far the only proposed profile is dCBOR. I think dCBOR exists just fine without the notion of application profiles, just like CDE exists just fine on top of preferred serialization.

To justify the complexity application profiles add, I think we'd want to have three solid use cases for them.

Application profiles are only for variations of CDE. They are not for variations of preferred serialization or a general profile mechanism for all of CBOR. This makes them much much less useful.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: Can you explain how giving the concept a name adds complexity?

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
Doesn't the burden of justification for something in a document lie with the proponent of the something?

A short answer to your question is that for us careful implementors every concept in a document must be read, digested, thought through and understood to be sure of correctness and completeness.

But, I don't think things should go in documents unless there is justification.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
Of course.  The most recent mail where I tried to explain the reason for them is Archived-At: <https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cbor/7CAgHZxvj34Rf4rcXFGeFwBzv_M>

To make a decision, it is necessary not only to understand the benefit, but also the cost of the feature.
To me it seems it creates zero cost for those who do not implement it.
If you think you do not need it, I would not implement it.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
I don't see how the cost is zero. You have to understand it to know that you don't have to implement it.

There's a cost to protocol designers too. They have to understand it to know whether they should use it or not use it.

There's also some cost to the WG, the IESG and the RFC editor to review.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
We could improve the text to make this easier to understand.

The cost of *not* having the feature is immense.
People will notice that their application data model does not map one-to-one to CDE and will do exactly what dCBOR did in the outset -- reinvent a incompatible variant of CDE because their application data model isn't identical to the generic data model of CBOR.

So it is absolutely worth massive effort to have application profiles as a concept in place.
I still believe the actual effort is minimal, and I would like to understand what text in CDE creates complexity for you, and how we could minimize the discovery cost for those whose actual cost is zero because they don't need it.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body:
The justification I am looking for is the description of some more compelling use cases to sit along side dCBOR. I don't think any have been described.

I don't see immensity here. If there was immensity, then there would be at least a couple of examples of bad variants of CDE. So far we only have one variant of CDE which IMO isn't too bad (other opinions aside).

Also, can you say why application profiles are justified for CDE, but not preferred serialization or a general profile mechanism for all of CBOR?

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: PR #15 should address most of your concerns, without removing the concept of Application Profiles entirely.

pulls.title: Prepare -01
pulls.author: cabo
pulls.body:
* b850713 Add some security considerations
* 0c91f68 Further clarifications
* 4731cab Clarify representation of NaNs
* 2190787 RECOMMENDS is not an RFC 2119 keyword
* 45bdbdc Do section references into STD documents as pioneered in RFC 9485
* cf3b06f Remove reference to I-D.bormann-cbor-dcbor

reviews.author: laurencelundblade
reviews.body: Hi Carsten, looks generally good. Thank you kindly for including. I made some comments, but am fine with merging as is.

comments.body:
Type 7 described in 8949 is deterministic without further specification. In particular, the text for simple values requires shortest-form. That's the reason I said all but type 7 and didn't call out an exemption for floats.

But, yes in the obvious implementation, the exception is floats.

I'm fine either way with the text.
Duplicate sentence.

I would remove "for instance". That text in 3.1 is _the_ normative unequivocal statement that duplicate map keys are not allowed. I kind of wish that text in 8949 was stronger.

Understand that some decoders might not detect this and that we have to allow such decoders, but that doesn't change the hard requirement that duplicate map keys are never allowed, right?

The text "support" is kind of being used as a form of 2119 SHOULD here. I'd much prefer saying decoders MAY support checking.  I don't think it is a SHOULD and would prefer to stick with 2119 terminology.
I like this wording. I was trying to figure out something like this myself.

But, it doesn't negate the main benefit of Preferred which is interoperability nor the main benefit of CDE which is determinism.

Having spent a year plus trying to understand benefit and negatives of stuff in COSE and HPKE, I'd much prefer explicit statement of negatives and benefits.
Yes!  That is the point...  We really mean this.

Correct, at least if you want to have valid encoded data items.
Removed the "for instance", but there are of course other places in 8949 that add information to this.
But citing them all here does not make sense, indeed.

This is really a "truth of advertising" statement, not a SHOULD.
So it is phrased as a factual "need to".

Not checking removes some security properties.

Section 5 (security considerations):

```
However, this effect only accrues if the decoder actually checks that
deterministic encoding was applied correctly.
```

This is just restated here...
Isn't this section 4.1 of 8949?  I assumed preferred serialization is capitalized here because it is the title of the section.
I think I'd make this not capitalized.

This was specifically about encoding of integers, 3.4.3:

```
The preferred serialization of an integer that can
   be represented using major type 0 or 1 is to encode it this way
   instead of as a bignum (which means that the empty string never
   occurs in a bignum when using preferred serialization)
```

Fixed the case, added "for all integers".

Sorry, emacs global substitute keeps the case; fixed this below.
Now mostly downcased.

pulls.title: Separate motivation (for the Introduction) and what an implementer needs to do
pulls.author: rohanmahy
pulls.body: Simplify Abstract; Move motivation to Introduction

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
Thank you!  I think I like what I'm seeing, but some assembly is still required.
Unfortunately, I ran out of time integrating this change; I plan to have this as part of -04 on 2024-07-21.

comments.author: laurencelundblade
comments.body: Oops. Not ready yet.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: You can keep it as a draft PR

pulls.title: Clarify concept of a CDE decoder and what it MUST do
pulls.author: cabo

pulls.title: NaN appendix
pulls.author: laurencelundblade
pulls.body:
It takes week or so to implement basic CBOR integer and float encoding. I’m not as smart as some here, but I get by… It took me many many months to figure out NaN payloads. I’ve put what I learned in a NaN Appendix to the CDE draft to save others these months.

It’s a fairly long addition, but it seems worthwhile to me to cover the details explicitly. It’s an appendix, not the main document, which signals to the reader that they don’t have to read it.

It makes a recommendation that protocol designers not use NaN payloads because there are better ways to accomplish the same.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
Thanks!  I think the most valuable part here is the table at the end.
The explanation probably should first explain that CBOR supports IEEE 754, what a NaN is, that a NaN always has a payload, and which payload values aren't available because they would mean something different than a NaN.  A quick discussion of the quiet/signaling bit, the fact that IEEE 754 doesn't define it, but there is a de facto standard needs to follow, and then we can introduce the "basic" NaN with sign 0, quiet bit 1, all other payload bits zero.  The reason why some applications are not using `foo = float / null` or `foo = float / payload` where payload can be anything but float.  Then a quick discussion of implementation considerations for preferred serialization, including the weirdness that two NaNs do not compare equal in most platforms, even if they are equal wrt to their payloads.

I'm not sure this shouldn't be a separate draft, to which CDE could refer for information.
It's night here already, but I could turn your input and the above outline into a draft about NaN and CBOR.

comments.author: cabo
comments.body: <https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cbor/KA7ma_UIESnM11SODvmoium9Uqc>

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
Now became part of https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-bormann-cbor-numbers/
Still needs to be referenced properly; ran out of time.

pulls.title: Application profile appendix
pulls.author: cabo
pulls.body:
Move the application profile section to an appendix.

Clarify the relationship between CDE and application
protocols/profiles some more.
Add "Structure of This Document".

comments.author: cabo
comments.body:
And while we are waiting for Martin Thomson's I-D template to catch up to recent tool changes:

https://tzi.org/~cabo/application-profile-appendix/
